title: State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh (1996)
principle: Rape is a crime against basic human rights and violates victim's right to life under Article 21. Conviction can be based on sole testimony of victim if credible.

title: Vishaka v. State of Rajasthan (1997)
principle: Laid down guidelines for prevention of sexual harassment at workplace. Employers must provide safe working environment and complaint mechanism.

title: State of Karnataka v. Appa Balu Ingale (1993)
principle: Cruelty under Section 498A IPC includes mental torture and harassment for dowry. Sustained harassment amounts to cruelty even without physical violence.

title: Sushil Kumar Sharma v. Union of India (2005)
principle: Section 498A IPC should not be used as weapon for vendetta. Arrest should not be automatic and mechanical. Police must satisfy themselves about credibility before arrest.

title: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014)
principle: Arrest not mandatory for offences punishable with less than 7 years imprisonment. Police must follow CrPC Section 41A notice procedure before arrest.

title: Rajesh Sharma v. State of UP (2017)
principle: Family Welfare Committees to be set up to prevent misuse of Section 498A. No automatic arrest of accused or their relatives without proper inquiry.

title: Shreya Singhal v. Union of India (2015)
principle: Section 66A of IT Act struck down as unconstitutional. Restrictions on free speech must be reasonable and within Article 19(2) exceptions.

title: State of Maharashtra v. Madhukar Narayan (1991)
principle: Terrorism cases require strict proof. Confessions under TADA admissible but must be corroborated. Courts must scrutinize evidence carefully.

title: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India (2018)
principle: Section 377 IPC decriminalized for consensual adult relations. Right to privacy and dignity under Article 21 includes sexual orientation.

title: K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India (2017)
principle: Right to privacy is fundamental right under Article 21. State surveillance and data collection must be proportionate and follow due process.
